Black Panther is part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU).
The film Black Panther was released in 2018.
In 1992, Wesley Snipes planned to make a Black Panther film but the project did not come to fruition.
In September 2005, Marvel Studios listed a Black Panther film as one of ten films based on Marvel characters intended to be distributed by Paramount Pictures.
In January 2011, Mark Bailey was hired to write a script for the Black Panther film.
Boseman made his first appearance as the Black Panther character in Captain America: Civil War (2016).
Coogler was announced as the Black director for the Black Panther film in October 2014.
Principal photography for the Black Panther film also took place in Busan, South Korea.
Black Panther is a film that is part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), which includes several other superhero movies.
The premiere of Black Panther took place at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles on January 29, 2018.
Black Panther was released as part of Phase Three of the MCU, which includes several other films such as Captain America: Civil War and Avengers: Infinity War.
Black Panther received critical acclaim from various critics, who praised its direction, writing, acting, costume design, production values, and soundtrack.
Some critics criticized the visual effects of Black Panther, but it still became a commercial and critical success.
Black Panther was also noted for its cultural significance due to its predominantly black cast and portrayal of African culture.
Black Panther received seven nominations at the 91st Academy Awards, winning three awards, including Best Costume Design, Best Original Score, and Best Production Design.
A television series set in Wakanda is currently in development for Disney+'s streaming service.

Thousands of years ago, five African tribes war over a meteorite containing the metal vibranium. The ingestion of a 'heart-shaped herb' affected by the metal results in the first Black Panther gaining superhuman abilities.

The Black Panther unites all but the Jabari Tribe to form the nation of Wakanda over centuries, using vibranium to develop advanced technologies and isolate themselves from the world by posing as an underdeveloped country.
In 1992, Wakanda king T'Chaka visits his brother N'Jobu, who is working undercover in Oakland, California.
T'Chaka accuses N'Jobu of assisting black-market arms dealer Ulysses Klaue with stealing vibranium from Wakanda.
N'Jobu's partner reveals he is Zuri, another undercover Wakandan, and confirms T'Chaka's suspicions.
Following T'Chaka's death, his son T'Challa returns to Wakanda to assume the throne and attends his coronation ceremony with his mother Ramonda and younger sister Shuri.

T'Challa and Okoye, leader of the Dora Milaje, extract T'Challa's ex-lover Nakia from an undercover assignment so she can attend his coronation ceremony with his mother Ramonda and younger sister Shuri.
At the ceremony, the Jabari Tribe's leader M'Baku challenges T'Challa for the crown in ritual combat without the benefit of the heart-shaped herb.
In the present day, following T'Chaka's death, his son T'Challa returns to Wakanda to assume the throne. He is a Black Panther with superhuman abilities.
When Klaue and his accomplice Erik Stevens steal a Wakandan artifact from a London museum, T'Challa's friend and Okoye's husband W'Kabi urges him to bring Klaue back alive.
Okoye travels with T'Challa, and Nakia to Busan, South Korea.
When Klaue and his accomplice Erik Stevens steal a Wakandan artifact from a London museum,
Klaue steals a Wakandan artifact from a London museum, and T'Challa stops him.
Erik Stevens is Klaue's accomplice.
Wakanda's international image is a front for a technologically advanced civilization, as revealed by Klaue to Ross.
When Klaue plans to sell the artifact to CIA agent Everett K. Ross, T'Challa, Okoye, and Nakia travel to Busan, South Korea.
Ross is gravely injured protecting Nakia.

When Klaue and his accomplice Erik Stevens steal a Wakandan artifact from a London museum, T'Challa's friend and Okoye's husband W'Kabi urges him to bring Klaue back alive. In Busan, South Korea, W'Kabi travels with T'Challa, and Nakia.
In Busan, South Korea, Okoye travels with T'Challa, and Nakia.
When Klaue plans to sell the artifact to CIA agent Everett K. Ross, Erik attacks and extracts Klaue as Ross is gravely injured protecting Nakia.

Zuri explains that N'Jobu had grown disillusioned with Wakanda's isolationism and planned to share Wakanda's technology with people of African descent around the world to help them conquer their oppressors with the help of Klaue. Before T'Chaka could arrest N'Jobu, the latter attacked Zuri and forced T'Chaka to kill him.

Killmonger challenges T'Challa to ritual combat, where he kills Zuri; without the powers of the heart-shaped herb, T'Challa is badly injured and thought dead after Killmonger hurls him over a waterfall.

N'Jobu had grown disillusioned with Wakanda's isolationism and planned to share Wakanda's technology with people of African descent around the world to help them conquer their oppressors with the help of Klaue.

This boy grew up to be Erik, a black ops U.S. Navy SEAL who adopted the nickname 'Killmonger'.

Killmonger reveals his identity as N'Jadaka and states his claim to the throne.

Supported by W'Kabi and his army, Killmonger prepares to distribute shipments of Wakandan weapons to operatives worldwide.

Coogler was chosen to direct the Black Panther movie by Marvel Studios president Kevin Feige in January 2016, making him the first African-American director of a Marvel Studios film.

In an interview with The Hollywood Reporter in April 2016, Feige revealed that Coogler was working on the script for Black Panther with Joe Robert Cole and that filming would begin at the beginning of 2017.
Feige announced in April 2016 that Black Panther would be the first Marvel Studios production to feature a 'primarily African-American cast'.
Nyong'o entered negotiations to star as T'Challa's love interest in Black Panther in April 2016.
Jordan joined the cast of Black Panther in an undisclosed role in May 2016, after previously working with director Ryan Coogler on Fruitvale Station and Creed.
Marvel Studios was planning to shoot Black Panther in Atlanta, Georgia by the end of May 2016.
Nate Moore, serving as a producer on Black Panther by the end of May 2016, revealed that Marvel Studios was 'definitely investigating shooting in Africa' for the film.
At San Diego Comic-Con 2016, Nyong'o was confirmed for the film as Nakia. Coogler confirmed that filming would begin in January 2017.
At San Diego Comic-Con 2016, Jordan's role was revealed to be Erik Killmonger.
Danai Gurira as Okoye was announced at San Diego Comic-Con 2016.
Winston Duke was cast as M'Baku in September 2016. Yahya Abdul-Mateen II also tested for the role.
Forest Whitaker was cast as Zuri in September 2016.
Daniel Kaluuya was cast as W'Kabi in September 2016.
Angela Bassett was cast as T'Challa's mother, Ramonda, in September 2016.
Sterling K. Brown was cast as N'Jobu in September 2016.
Letitia Wright was cast in an unspecified role in September 2016. Florence Kasumba was also revealed to be reprising her role as Ayo.
Marvel received permission from AC Transit in January 2017 to use their logo in the film for the opening flashback.
The setting of the opening flashback sequence was chosen due to Coogler growing up in that area, and permission was granted by AC Transit to use their logo in the film.

In Black Panther, the Wakandan language was introduced based on the Xhosa language, which was taught to actors portraying Wakandans in the film by John Kani, who played T'Challa's father. Director Ryan Coogler made the use of the language a priority and incorporated it in natural and authentic situations.
In Black Panther, T'Challa's father, King T'Chaka, was portrayed by John Kani. This connection highlights the significance of T'Chaka in Black Panther and his relation to T'Challa.
According to Feige, Black Panther served as a very important link between MCU films like Captain America: Civil War and Avengers: Infinity War and Avengers: Endgame.

Rooted in the actual cultures of Africa, the filmmakers consulted with experts on the region of Africa that Wakanda is supposed to be located in. Cole called the film an historic opportunity to depict a Black superhero 'at a time when African-Americans are affirming their identities while dealing with vilification and dehumanization'. Wakanda's traditional blankets, inspired by Lesotho, are featured in the film.

Coogler compared the rarity of vibranium existing only in Wakanda to the real-life mineral coltan that can almost only be found in Congo. The country's traditional blankets, inspired by Lesotho, are also featured in the film.
Coogler compared the rarity of vibranium existing only in Wakanda to the real-life mineral coltan that can almost only be found in Congo.
Coogler created a project bible that detailed each Wakandan tribe to guide the design process. He wanted Wakanda to feel like a full country with multiple distinct tribes.
Beachler wanted to honor the comic designs by filling in the gaps with research concentrated on Sub-Saharan Africa. He pulled inspiration from Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Congo-Kinshasa, Ethiopia.

Beachler looked at the architecture of Zaha Hadid and incorporated circular motifs signifying the transmission of energy throughout the film, especially in older locations like Warrior Falls and the City of the Dead.

node_2: historic mali empire and the city of timbuktu
edge: Beachler looked at the architecture of existing tribes and took inspiration from the historic Mali Empire and the city of Timbuktu.
The Golden City, Wakanda's capital, has an Afro-punk style inspired by Sub-Saharan Africa.
Rondavels were incorporated into the tops of Wakanda's skyscrapers, inspired by the appearance of mountains at Blyde River Canyon in South Africa.
Beachler created different sigils and architecture for each of the Wakandan tribes, with the Border Tribe inspired by Lesotho.
Beachler created different sigils and architecture for each of the Wakandan tribes, with the Merchant Tribe having a sigil based on Nigerian writing.
Beachler created different sigils and architecture for each of the Wakandan tribes, with the Golden Tribe using a sun symbol found throughout Africa.
Gorilla City, home to the Jabari Tribe, was originally set in a rain forest, but Coogler suggested that it be found up a mountain in snow.
Beachler based the written form of the Wakandan language on an old Nigerian language.

Beachler consulted with mining and metallurgy experts for the vibranium technology, including for the vibranium mine where the substance is depicted as glowing blue rocks before it is refined into the stainless steel look previously seen in the MCU.
The film also adapts the kimoyo bead technology from the comics,

The Wakandan vehicles include a maglev train for carrying vibranium; the king's Royal Talon Fighter, which looks like a mask from the top and bottom; and the Dragon Flyer, inspired by the Congo peafowl.

node_2: consistency with projections of what real world technology may be like in 25 or 30 years
edge: The Wakandan futuristic elements were consistent with projections of what real world technology may be like in 25 or 30 years, such as the maglev and hovercraft technology used in vehicles.
The Tribal Council set was built with a glass floor through which an old ruin can be seen.

The set for Warrior Falls, which includes 30-foot-high (9.1 m) cliff faces that were designed to be extended to 100 feet (30 m), has a hand-sculpted framework from industrial styrofoam built into it.

The set for Warrior Falls, which includes a system of tunnels built-in to the design to allow extras to climb up to different areas of the cliffs, was completed in four months and used for two weeks of filming.
The design of the 30-foot-high (9.1 m) cliff faces in the set for Warrior Falls was inspired by Oribi Gorge.

The visual effects department had to individually model each digital extra for the sequence due to the precise costume designs created by Carter for each tribe and character, as copy-and-pasting around the set would not be authentic to African culture and geography.

Visual effects were used to digitally add some grey to T'Chaka's beard and gold trimmings to his suit to help differentiate the characters of T'Chaka and T'Challa, both dressed as the Black Panther, after test audiences were confusing the two.

ILM VFX supervisor Craig Hammack compared this work to his time on Tomorrowland (2015), but noted the additional challenge of not just building a futuristic city, but also one that was culturally appropriate. African culture has a 'certain amount of earthy material qualities that make things difficult to design as a futuristic city,' which would typically use much steel and glass.

node_2: one central park in sydney and the pearl of africa hotel in kampala
edge: ILM looked to real life examples that blend modern architecture with natural environments like One Central Park in Sydney and The Pearl of Africa Hotel in Kampala, but also had to 'depart from a strict understanding of physics and go into a movie cheat world' at times to produce the desired look.
Hammack was also inspired by the architecture of Uganda, where he spent time while aerial footage for the film was being shot.

ILM began work on [Wakanda] and also the last thing they were doing when the film was completed. Other things that ILM worked on during the production included set extensions and blue-screen replacements for interior sets, and the first rhinoceros shown in the film.

Manohla Dargis praised the writing for its handling of themes related to Africans, specifically highlighting how it explored the concept of Black imagination. This highlights a relationship between the ideas of African heritage and the imaginative processes that result in cultural creation.
Manohla Dargis honored Black Panther as an 'emblem of a past that was denied and a future that feels very present' due to its focus on Black imagination, creation, and liberation.

Kenneth Turan praised the themes of the film and their exploration of what wealthy countries owe to the poor and oppressed, implying a relationship between wealth and poverty as well as the responsibilities of those in positions of power.
The film 'draws energy from Coogler's sense of excitement at all he's attempting', according to Kenneth Turan, and this excitement is tied to the themes of isolationism and revolution.

node_2: tones of whiz-bang action sequences and good humor
edge: Richard Roeper, writing for the Chicago Sun-Times, said audiences should watch the film if they appreciate 'finely honed storytelling with a Shakespearean core; winning performances from an enormously talented ensemble; provocative premises touching on isolationism, revolution and cultures of oppression, and oh yeah, tons of whiz-bang action sequences and good humor'

Brian Truitt of USA Today stated, 'While the themes are deep, Black Panther is at the same time a visual joy to behold, with confident quirkiness, insane action sequences and special effects, and the glorious reveal of Wakanda'

Many have wondered why Black Panther means so much to the Black community and why schools, churches, and organizations have come to theaters with excitement. The answer is that the movie brings a moment of positivity to a group of people often not the centerpiece of Hollywood movies..., [Racial and ethnic socialization] helps to strengthen identity and helps reduce the likelihood on internalizing negative stereotypes about one's ethnic group.
Bouie said, 'it is fair to say that Black Panther is the most political movie ever produced by Marvel Studios, both in its very existence... And in the questions its story raises.'
Natasha Alford of The Grio called the film a 'movement, a revolution in progress, and a joy to experience all wrapped into one'

Jamie Broadnax of Black Girl Nerds called the film a masterpiece that is 'afro-futuristic and Blackity-black as hell. It's everything I've ever desired in a live-action version of this popular superhero and yet so much more.'
The film's success proves that African-American narratives can generate profits from all audiences.
The film challenges institutional bias through its themes.
The film's characters take unsubtle digs at oppressors.

edge: Killmonger is given the 'most hideous traits imaginable [making] the only major African-American character and agitator for revolution a manic killer consumed by rage and violence', as stated by James Wilt, writing for Canadian Dimension.

'at its core, Black Panther contains a fundamentally reactionary understanding of Black liberation that blatantly advocates respectability politics over revolution', as stated by James Wilt, writing for Canadian Dimension.
Killmonger's role as a character is 'to discredit radical internationalism', as stated by Russell Rickford of Africa is a Country.
The only Islamic characters in the film are a Boko Haram-based group that kidnapped several girls and forced them to wear hijab, as stated by Faisal Kutty from Middle East Eye.

The director of the National Academy of Sciences, Richard Loverd, believes that Black Panther will increase interest in science, technology, and Africa for young Black Americans in a way similar to how The Hunger Games films and Brave sparked girls' interest in archery. This suggests that Black Panther can be seen as a type of comic book film and that it may attract audiences who typically do not watch this genre due to its unique representation of African culture.

Broadnax, a cultural critic and creator, notes that Black Panther will be significant for people who generally do not watch comic book films because they can see themselves reflected in a major way that has not been possible before. This highlights the significance of representation in popular culture and how it can bridge gaps between different communities.

Broadnax also mentions that the strong female characters, such as Shuri, in Black Panther will serve as an inspiration for girls. This highlights how representation can impact gender and empower women through their portrayal in popular culture.
Gil Robertson, co-founder and president of the African American Film Critics Association, called the film 'critically important' and a 'gate-opener opportunity for other Black-centered projects'.
Child development expert Deborah Gilboa felt the film would 'make a huge impact on children's spirits' by offering positive role models.

Scholar Marlene D. Allen felt the women of Wakanda 'are the very definition of 'Black Girl Magic', a term coined by CaShawn Thompson in 2013 'to celebrate the beauty, power, and resilience of Black women.'

Tre Johnson of Rolling Stone felt that 'after decades of trying to nail the modern Black superhero, we may finally be getting what we've asked for', with Johnson saying Black Panther felt different from the Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and the 'Blaxploitation-lite' attempts at Black superhero films in the 1990s and 2000s because it was 'respectable, imaginative and powerful', setting 'a new direction' for the depiction of Black superheroes.

In the film's opening weekend, 37% of audiences in the United States were African-American, according to PostTrak, compared to 35% Caucasian, 18% Hispanic, and 5% Asian. This was the most diverse audience for a superhero film ever.

node_2: children of color at the boys & girls club in harlem
edge: philanthropist Frederick Joseph created a GoFundMe drive to raise money for underserved children of color to see Black Panther, as it was a rare opportunity for them to see a Black major comic book character brought to film. The drive raised over $45,000, exceeding its goal, with the money also funding other programs for children in Harlem. Joseph encouraged others to create similar drives for their communities through the 'Black Panther Challenge', which resulted in 400 additional drives being started around the world and made the overall drive the largest GoFundMe in history for an entertainment event, raising over $400,00.
Joseph promoted the GoFundMe drive for children of color at the Boys & Girls Club in Harlem to see Black Panther with Boseman on The Ellen DeGeneres Show.

node_2: smithsonian institution's national museum of african american history and culture
edge: In June 2018, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of African American History and Culture announced that they had acquired Chadwick Boseman's Black Panther costume for their collection. This addition provides a 'fuller story of Black culture and identity' by showcasing the progression of Black Americans in film and challenging the industry's past practice of regulating them to one-dimensional and marginalized figures.

The Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of African American History and Culture acquired Chadwick Boseman's Black Panther costume in June 2018. As the lead actor in the film, Boseman's costume represents his portrayal of the titular character and adds to the museum's collection showcasing the progression of Black Americans in film.

By late August 2018, Disney hired Academy Award campaign strategist Cynthia Swartz to create a nomination campaign on behalf of the film for the 91st Academy Awards. The campaign was focused to highlight 'the film’s creative accomplishments and the global impact it made' in the hopes of receiving a Best Picture nomination.

node_2: auteur-driven superhero movie possessing a deep significance both to its director and to people historically underrepresented in hollywood films.
edge: Glenn Whipp of the Los Angeles Times felt the 'blueprint' for the film’s Best Picture campaign was to 'communicate to Oscar voters that this is an auteur-driven superhero movie possessing a deep significance both to its director and to people historically underrepresented in Hollywood films.'
Reminding the Oscar voters 'Black Panther wasn’t just a movie, it was a phenomenon' would help the film earn a nomination.
Oscar campaign consultant said voters 'want to reward good movies and they also want to reward movies that say something significant'
